intermediate.q: If you _____ the button, the machine starts automatically.
intermediate.exp: Zero conditional uses present simple in both clauses for things that always happen.

intermediate.q: If it _____ tomorrow, we will cancel the picnic.
intermediate.exp: First conditional: present simple in if-clause for real future possibility.

intermediate.q: Unless you _____ harder, you won't pass the exam.
intermediate.exp: 'Unless' means 'if not' and requires present simple in first conditional.

intermediate.q: If I _____ time tomorrow, I will help you with the project.
intermediate.exp: First conditional: present simple after 'if' for future possibility.

intermediate.q: Water _____ if you heat it to 100 degrees Celsius.
intermediate.exp: Zero conditional for scientific facts - present simple in both clauses.

intermediate.q: If she _____ the train, she will arrive by 6 o'clock.
intermediate.exp: First conditional: present simple in if-clause, 'will' in main clause.

upper.q: Should you _____ any problems, please contact customer support immediately.
upper.exp: Formal first conditional: 'should + subject' = 'if + present simple'.

upper.q: Provided that everyone _____ their part, the project will be completed on time.
upper.exp: 'Provided that' requires present simple for future conditions.

upper.q: If the company _____ to expand overseas, it will need more investment.
upper.exp: First conditional: present simple for real future possibility.

upper.q: Unless the situation _____, we will have to take further action.
upper.exp: 'Unless' (if not) takes present simple in first conditional.

intermediate.q: If I _____ a million dollars, I would travel around the world.
intermediate.exp: Second conditional: past simple in if-clause for unreal present situation.

intermediate.q: If they _____ harder last year, they would have passed the exam.
intermediate.exp: Third conditional: past perfect in if-clause for unreal past situation.

intermediate.q: I would buy that car if I _____ enough money.
intermediate.exp: Second conditional: past simple for hypothetical present situation.

intermediate.q: If we _____ earlier, we wouldn't have missed the train.
intermediate.exp: Third conditional: past perfect for unreal past action.

intermediate.q: She would help you if she _____ how to solve the problem.
intermediate.exp: Second conditional: past simple for hypothetical present knowledge.

intermediate.q: If you _____ me about the party, I would have come.
intermediate.exp: Third conditional: past perfect for unreal past situation.

upper.q: Had I known about the meeting, I _____ attended.
upper.exp: Inverted third conditional: 'had + subject + past participle' requires 'would have' in main clause.

upper.q: If the manager _____ more carefully, the mistake could have been avoided.
upper.exp: Third conditional: past perfect for unreal past action affecting past result.

upper.q: Were I in your position, I _____ differently.
upper.exp: Inverted second conditional: 'were + subject' requires 'would' in main clause.

upper.q: If the team _____ more experience, they would have won the competition.
upper.exp: Third conditional: past perfect for unreal past situation.

intermediate.q: If I _____ Spanish at school, I could work in Spain now.
intermediate.exp: Mixed conditional: past perfect (past) → present conditional result.

intermediate.q: If she _____ more responsible, she wouldn't have lost her job last month.
intermediate.exp: Mixed conditional: past perfect (past state) → past result.

intermediate.q: If they _____ the house in 2010, they would be rich today.
intermediate.exp: Mixed third→second: past perfect (past action) → present result.

upper.q: Had we invested in that company, we _____ financially secure now.
upper.exp: Mixed third→second: inverted past perfect → present conditional result.

upper.q: If the government _____ action earlier, the economy would be stronger today.
upper.exp: Mixed conditional: past perfect (past inaction) → present consequence.

intermediate.q: You will pass the test _____ you study regularly.
_____ I win the lottery, I would buy a big house.
intermediate.exp: 'Should' in inverted first conditional for unlikely future event.

intermediate.q: We won't go to the beach _____ it stops raining.
intermediate.exp: 'Unless' means 'if not' - won't go if it doesn't stop raining.

upper.q: _____ anyone call, please take a message.
upper.exp: Formal inverted first conditional: 'should' for possible future event.

upper.q: The project will succeed _____ adequate funding is secured.
